questions.text: A 40-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with chest pain. His ECG was done. The below ECG indicates-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal ECG In the above given ECG- P wave axis is abnormal- upright in aVR and negative in II With the reversal of the LA and RA electrodes, Einthoven’s triangle flips 180 degrees horizontally around an axis formed by lead aVF.

Highyeild:

This has the following effects on the ECG: Lead I becomes inverted Leads II and III switch places Leads aVL and aVR switch places Lead aVF remains unchanged Lead I is completely inverted (P wave, QRS complex, and T wave) Lead aVR often becomes positive There may be marked right-axis deviation So, Options A and B are not the correct choices.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding Phase 0 of the action potential in the ECG QRS-T waveform Hyperkalemia decreases the slope of phase 0 It is a rapid upstroke Drugs like flecainide increases the slope of phase 0 Corresponds to the onset of QRS Select the correct Options from given below code:-

options.label: A
options.text: All the above statements are true

questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,4- true; 3- false Drugs like flecainide decrease the slope of phase 0 by impairing the influx of Na+. not increase. The QRS-T waveforms of the surface ECG correspond in a general way with the different phases of simultaneously obtained ventricular action potentials, the intracellular recordings from single myocardial fibers The rapid upstroke ( phase 0) of the action potential corresponds to the onset of QRS. Factors that decrease the slope of phase 0 by impairing the influx of Na+ (e.g., hyperkalemia and drugs such as flecainide ) tend to increase QRS duration. Therefore, option C is correct and options A, B, and D are false.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of ECG?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T wave It is a JVP waveform. The wave is caused by the contraction of the right atrium

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- The ECG waveforms are labeled alphabetically, Option B - begins with the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization (Fig. 235-2). The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, and the ST-T-U complex (ST segment, T wave, and U wave) represents ventricular repolarization. The J point is the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment. Options A and D - The normal U wave is a small, rounded deflection (≤1 mm) that follows the T wave and usually has the same polarity as the T wave. An abnormal increase in U-wave amplitude is most commonly due to drugs (e.g., dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol, quinidine) or to hypokalemia

questions.text: True/False regarding the Atrial repolarization waveforms - (i) Too low in amplitude (ii) P wave represents atrial repolarization (iii) this waveform may become apparent in acute pericarditis, atrial infarction, and AV heart block (iv) high amplitude Select the correct Options from given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

(i),(ii)- True; (iii),(iv)- False Atrial repolarization waveforms (ST-Ta ) are usually of too low in amplitude to be detected, it may become apparent in acute pericarditis, atrial infarction, and AV heart block P wave represents atrial depolarization.

questions.text: The cardiac action potential is a measurement of the membrane potential waveform of the cardiac myocytes signifying the electrical activity of the cell during the contraction and relaxation of the heart. Specific ionic currents contribute to each phase of the cardiac action potential. For phase 3 of the action potential of ECG all of the following statements are true except-

options.label: A
options.text: Digoxin prolongs phase 3 of action potential

options.label: B
options.text: Corresponds to the inscription of the T wave

options.label: C
options.text: It is a phase of active repolarization

options.label: D
options.text: Amiodarone prolongs phase 3 of action potential

questions.correct_answer: A. Digoxin prolongs phase 3 of action potential
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corresponds to the inscription of the T wave Digoxin is associated with the shortening of ventricular repolarization duration to shorten the QT. It does not prolong phase 3 of the action potential.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B and C .-Active repolarization (phase 3) correspond to the inscription of the T wave- Option D -Conditions that prolong phase 2 or 3 (amiodarone, hypocalcemia) increase the QT interval. In contrast, factors (e.g., hypercalcemia, digoxin) associated with the shortening of ventricular repolarization duration shorten the QT

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty with fatigue and dizziness. Her ECG was as below. Her Heart rate is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

60 beats/min The instantaneous heart rate (beats per minute) can be computed from the interbeat (RR) interval by dividing the number of large (0.20 s) time units between consecutive R waves into 300 or the number of small (0.04 s) units into 1500. Therefore - 300 / 06 = about 50 beats/min The PR interval measures the time (normally 120–200 ms) between atrial and ventricular depolarization, which includes the physiologic delay imposed by stimulation of cells in the AV junction area. The QRS interval (normally 100–110 ms or less) reflects the duration of ventricular depolarization. Therefore, the answer is option B. Options A, C, and D are not correct.

questions.text: There are three main components to an ECG: the P wave, which represents depolarization of the atria; the QRS complex, which represents depolarization of the ventricles; and the T wave, which represents repolarization of the ventricles. Which part of the ECG is known as the plateau phase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ST segment The plateau (phase 2) corresponds to the isoelectric ST segment
